textRegions.text: We want you to be successful and make a difference
Instead of Engineering InfoSec became actuaries

[risk assessment] introduces a dangerous fallacy: that structured inadequacy is almost as good as adequacy and that underfunded security efforts plus risk management are about as good as properly funded security work - Michal Zalewski
Why cant you give a better answer?
The Inequitable Distribution of Labor in Security Mimics That in Dev/Ops
2% of an Engineering Dev Team are working on Security

Adversity is Real or
perceived negative
actions and events that prohibit normal
function and operation.
Building solutions to handle adversity will cause unintended, positive benefits that will provide value that would have been unrealized otherwise.

-Surviving Lulz: Behind the Scenes of LulzSec @SXSW 2012
by CloudFlare team

Rugged By Design,
DevOps By Culture

repeatable  no manual steps, CI
reliable - no DoS herereviewable  aka audit, Infra as Coderapid  fast to build, deploy, restoreresilient  automated reconfiguration 
reduced - limited attack surface
gauntlt is built for doing security testing in a DevOps world
accessible to everyone involved in dev, ops, testing, security, ...
Security domain knowledge is generally a mystery to dev teams
gauntlt allows dev and ops and security to communicate

$ gem install gauntlt

# download example attacks from github
# customize the example attacks 
# now you can run gauntlt

$ gauntlt
lets look inside a couple of these files

@slowFeature: nmap attacks for example.com  Background:    Given "nmap" is installed    And the target hostname is "www.example.com"    And the target tcp_ping_ports are "22,25,80,443"  Scenario: Verify server is open on expected set of ports using the nmap fast flag    When I launch an "nmap" attack with:      """      nmap -F <hostname>      """    Then the output should contain:      """      80/tcp  open  https      """  Scenario: Verify that there are no unexpected ports open    When I launch an "nmap" attack with:      """      nmap -F <hostname>      """    Then the output should not contain:      """      25/tcp      """

wickett$ gauntlt

@slowFeature: nmap attacks for example.com  Background:  
    Given "nmap" is installed    And the target hostname is "www.example.com" 
    And the target tcp_ping_ports are "22,25,80,443"   Scenario: Verify server is open on expected set of ports using the nmap fast flag     
    When   I launch an "nmap" attack with:                              """      nmap -F www-stage.cloudsourcery.com      """    Then the output should contain:                         
      """      443/tcp  open  https      """1 scenario (1 failed)5 steps (1 failed, 4 passed)0m18.341s

Netflix is a heavy AWS user, and we provide self-service deployment for dev teams
Netflix is a heavy AWS user, and we provide self-service deployment for dev teams
AWS Elastic Load Balancer (ELB) provides cross-datacenter traffic balancing, but no security controls (if your cluster is attached to an ELB, it is available to the Internet)
Netflix is a heavy AWS user, and we provide self-service deployment for dev teams
AWS Elastic Load Balancer (ELB) provides cross-datacenter traffic balancing, but no security controls (if your cluster is attached to an ELB, it is available to the Internet)
Engineers may misunderstand use cases for ELBs, security features, and/or other measures that can be used to protect ELB-fronted clusters
How do we ensure the 100s of clusters associated with ELBs are configured and protected as intended?
Solution: Use gauntlt to organize and perform ELB testing
What response will an ELB provide to an arbitrary Internet node, and is it expected?
Launch gauntlt test runner instance, loaded with master list of ELBs and expected state

Any organization that designs a system ... will inevitably produce a design whose structure is a copy of the organization's communication structure.

BDD is a second-generation, outsidein, pull-based, multiple-stakeholder, multiple-scale, high-automation, agile methodology. It describes a cycle of interactions with well-defined outputs, resulting in the delivery of working, tested software that matters.

Given /^"sqlmap" is installed$/ do   ensure_python_script_installed('sqlmap') end  When /^I launch an? "sqlmap" attack with:$/ do |command|   sqlmap_path = path_to_python_script("sqlmap")    command.gsub!('<target_url>', target_url)   command.gsub!('<sqlmap_path>', sqlmap_path)   run command end

notes.slide-90: We've seen some great examples of how people are using Gauntlt today, and how it can help ensure the security of your your apps and your infrastructure. Now, I'd like to spend a little time showing you an easy way to try Gauntlt out for yourself.
notes.slide-96:
vagrant box add precise32 
This the base image we're building the starter kit on.
notes.slide-91: First, a brief introduction. I'm Jeremiah Shirk, and I am the Integration & Infrastructure Manager at Kansas State University. Basically, we have a couple of dev and sysadmin teams responsible for the environments that run enterprise web applications. Recently, we've adopted a few ideas from Agile and DevOps, and Gauntlt is a good fit for we're trying to do there.
notes.slide-4: OWASP involvement since 2006.  President from 2006 to 2009.
notes.slide-100: Once the VM is up and running, you just use vagrant ssh to log in to the VM.
notes.slide-97: This starts up the VM, and applies the configs in the Vagrantfile
notes.slide-92: SoGauntlt. To make it easy to try this out, we've put together a starter kit, that packages gauntlt, all of it's dependencies, and some simple examples, into a virtual machine. All you need to do it download the kit, fire up the VM, and in a few minutes you'll be running gauntlt yourself. Once you decide you want to do more with it, we've also got detailed docs on how to set up a production install.
notes.slide-98: I included a video of Chef running to configure the VM.  Its sped up quite a bit.  When youre doing this for real, its a good time to grab a cup of coffee.
notes.slide-104: Alright, that's it for the examples in the starter kit, for now. I'm hoping you all will try this out for yourself. Go to www.gauntlt.org for all of the docs, and you'll also find a short screencast coving most of the steps I talked about today.
notes.slide-93: To use the kit, there are a couple of prerequisites. You might already have these on your machine. First, VirtualBox, for running the VM. The other is Vagrant. You might not have this yet, but I'd say that for 90% of you, if you don't already use Vagrant, you probably should. Vagrant uses VirtualBox to "Create and configure lightweight, reproducible, and portable development environments." IMAGE: (standard linux image) + (Vagrantfile) == customized, reproducible VM ready to go
notes.slide-99:
The Vagrantfile tells vagrant how to configure the VM with memory, network, etc.
And provision the OS, i.e. with puppet or chef
notes.slide-101: There is something about Vagrant that you should be aware of. Out of the box, all Vagrant VMs use the same SSH keys. Most users replace them. You should probably do the same. There is a script in the starter kit, replace-ssh-keys.sh. You'll want to run that immediately after bringing up the VM for the first time.
notes.slide-94: If you don't already have these installed, you can just download them from their websites.
notes.slide-105: We'll be holding "office hours" this evening, starting at 10pm somewhere near the hotel bar. Stop by if you have any questions, want to talk more about the project, or just to say hi. Thank you all again for joining us.
notes.slide-95: The next thing you'll want to do is grab the starter kit. It's available on GitHib. You can either clone the repo, or download a copy at LINK. Either way, cd into the starter kit directory, and run a few commands.
